name: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
description: Identity and Access Management (IAM) is your frontline defense for controlling who can access your cloud environment and what they can do once they're in. Before you secure your Journal API, you need to understand IAM fundamentals.

learning_steps.description: Start with your cloud provider's IAM documentation:
Video tutorials for your cloud provider:

• Users - Individual people or applications
• Groups - Collections of users with similar permissions
• Roles - Set of permissions that can be assumed
• Policies - Documents that define permissions
Give users and services only the minimum permissions needed to do their job. This reduces the impact if credentials are compromised.

• User accounts - For people who need to access resources
• Service accounts - For applications and services to access resources

• Authentication - Who are you? (login, MFA)
• Authorization - What can you do? (permissions, policies)

questions.prompt: Walk me through the difference between authentication and authorization in cloud security.
scenario_seeds: A new developer joined your team and was given admin access to troubleshoot a production issue. Later, you discover they accidentally deleted critical resources. Walk me through how proper authentication and authorization controls could have prevented this.
Your company's API is experiencing unauthorized data access even though users are logging in with valid credentials. Explain how authentication succeeded but authorization failed, and how to fix it.

A contractor needs temporary access to view logs in your cloud environment but shouldn't be able to modify anything. Describe how you'd configure authentication and authorization to meet this requirement.
questions.grading_rubric: Must clearly distinguish authentication (verifying identity - who you are) from authorization (granting permissions - what you can do) AND provide concrete examples of each AND explain how they work together in a secure system.

questions.prompt: How would you decide between using a service account versus a user account in cloud environments?
scenario_seeds: Your CI/CD pipeline needs to deploy containers to production every night at 2 AM. A team member suggests using their personal cloud credentials in the pipeline. Explain why this is problematic and what you'd use instead.

An application running in Kubernetes needs to read secrets from your cloud provider's secrets manager. How would you set up the identity for this application, and why wouldn't you use a developer's credentials?

Your data engineering team runs scheduled jobs that process customer data. Some engineers want to use their own accounts for these jobs so they can debug issues. Explain the security implications and your recommended approach.
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain that service accounts are for automated/programmatic workloads while user accounts are for human interactive access AND discuss credential management differences AND address security implications of each choice.

test_knowledge_prompts: Can you quiz me on the difference between IAM users, groups, and roles?
Can you ask me to explain the principle of least privilege with examples?
Can you test my knowledge of when to use service accounts vs user accounts?
Can you quiz me on the difference between authentication and authorization?
Can you ask me about common IAM security mistakes and how to prevent them?
Can you test my understanding of IAM policies and how they work?
Can you quiz me on when and why to use multi-factor authentication?
Can you ask me about workload identity and why it's better than long-lived keys?
